The evolving epidemiology of the disease and the expansion of at-risk areas have been associated with prolonged periods of increased rainfall and temperatures and with environmental perturbations arising from human activity (eg, deforestation, population movements, and changes in land use).
2 The resurgence of yellow fever, however, has been attributed largely to lapses of continuous vaccination coverage and the waning of population immunity in areas of yellow fever transmission, which makes outbreaks more frequent.
3 It is estimated that 393·7–472·9 million people will require vaccination
4 to achieve the population immunity recommended by WHO for countries at risk.
